description.plain:
Dwayne Michael Carter, Jr., better known by his stage name Lil Wayne, grew up in the Hollygrove neighborhood of New Orleans, Louisiana.

At the age of nine, Lil Wayne joined Cash Money Records as the youngest member of the label, and half of the duo, The B.G.‘z, with B.G.. In 1997, Lil Wayne joined the group Hot Boys, which also included rappers Juvenile, B.G., and Young Turk. Lil Wayne gained most of his success with the group’s major selling album Guerrilla Warfare, released in 1999. He has been listed in the 2012 Guinness Book Of World Records for the record of Most US Hot 100 Hits By A Rap Artist with 64 hits between 1999 and 2010.

Wayne is famous for his command of slow, witty lines and metaphorical jokes. His discography includes a slew of successful mixtapes, including Dedication 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6; No Ceilings; and Da Drought 3. His albums consistently garner acclaim, with Tha Carter series all platinum hits. Tha Carter series has been a work of Wayne’s for 13 years and continues to grow with the fifth installment, Tha Carter V released in 2018 (however, it was initially supposed to be released in late 2014). Wayne keeps a regular recording schedule, with studio booths in his tour bus, home, and following him everywhere.

songs.full_title: Love Me by Lil Wayne (Ft. Drake & Future)
songs.title: Love Me

description.plain:
On “Love Me,” Weezy, Drake, and Future talk about their women and how they care about nothing but them—as long as they love them back. It was released as the second single from Wayne’s tenth studio album, I Am Not a Human Being II.

The song was a success, peaking at #9 on the Billboard Hot 100—notably becoming Future’s first and only top ten single until he released “Mask Off” in February 2017, which peaked at #5.

The official music video premiered on February 14, 2013, on MTV Jams. In an interview with MTV News a day prior, Wayne talked about the concept of the music video:

The concept of the video is really just to create awesome scenery. A scenery that every man… anyone wanna be in […] I appreciate Drake and Future for doin’ this because I’m quite sure they’re hella busy like I am, but I ain’t never too busy to get in a bed with three women, with water everywhere.

songs.title: Believe Me

description.plain:
Floyd Mayweather Instagrammed footage of the studio session when Wayne and Drake were recording this.

Drake addresses his mentor and career succession. Mostly he talks about the fact that rappers don’t know his potential yet and are pushing him over the edge.

Wayne performed the track the night after its release at the Floyd Mayweather fight.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uiIrN24c2Xg

Drake previewed a snippet of the track at a club, prior to the song’s official release.

songs.full_title: Mona Lisa by Lil Wayne (Ft. Kendrick Lamar)
songs.title: Mona Lisa

description.plain:
“Mona Lisa” is a story of a deceptive woman named Liz who sets her “boyfriend” up for a robbery.

Liz is compared to the famous portrait painting due to the dubiety of Mona Lisa’s smile. The smile can be interpreted as disingenuous, which therefore makes Liz disingenuous as well, unbeknownst to the boyfriend. Wayne and Kendrick play the two sides of the story; Wayne is the robber and Kendrick is the boyfriend.

The song was originally recorded in 2014, as it appeared on the tentative Carter V tracklist that Wayne previewed in October 2014. The first snippet of the song was brought to light in 2017 when PharmaBro Martin Shkreli played a part of the song live on Periscope, after acquiring the album from a man who bought Lil Wayne’s Bugatti, where a copy of the album was left. The version that Shkreli played live was later leaked in September 2019, along with the rest of the original Carter V album.

 The song also notably contains references to Wayne’s relationship with Karrine Steffans, who is also known as Superhead. In an interview with BET Digital shortly after the song’s release, Steffans confirmed this, noting the song’s lyrics bared “similarities” to her relationship with Wayne.

songs.title: Mirror

description.plain:
With a sung portion by Bruno Mars, himself a subject of some strong opinions, this song examines Weezy’s past relationship with drugs and where it could lead him in the future.

Notably, the entire track sees Wayne talking to his reflection in a mirror, self-reflecting in an attempt to truly “see Wayne”.

songs.full_title: Rich As Fuck by Lil Wayne (Ft. 2 Chainz)
songs.title: Rich As Fuck

description.plain:
“Rich As Fuck” is a braggadocious anthem on which Lil Wayne and 2 Chainz flex their personal and crew’s wealth.

“Rich As Fuck” was the third and final single off Wayne’s tenth studio album I AM NOT A HUMAN BEING II. It peaked at #38 on the Billboard 100 chart and was later certified platinum by RIIA.

On the “leak version,” the two verses are inverted, contrary to the iTunes Version.

The music video premiered on March 22, 2013 via MTV.

songs.title: A Milli

description.plain:
As the late Senator Everett Dirksen is popularly attributed as having said, “A million here, a million there, and pretty soon you’re talking real money!”

Bangladesh produced the song but has not received a penny of royalties from Cash Money.

In addition, this entire song was taken in one take. Wayne has claimed that the verses were freestyles.

songs.full_title: Don't Cry by Lil Wayne (Ft. XXXTENTACION)
songs.title: Don’t Cry

description.plain:
“Don’t Cry,” the first song on Tha Carter V, features a chorus from the late XXXTENTACION. This song mainly focuses on Lil Wayne’s emotions as he discusses many difficult situations in his life. There is a smooth transition from the album’s intro, “I Love You Dwayne,” to this song, as we hear Jacida Carter (Lil Wayne’s mother) weeping before X tells her not to cry.

X had no knowledge that he would appear on Tha Carter V because his contributions were added after his passing. X met with Z3N, one of the song’s producers, in February 2018 to record this chorus and other music. Then, in August 2018, Z3N showed some of the music he created with X to LunchMoney Lewis, a Young Money affiliate. Lewis loved the chorus and showed it to Wayne and Republic Records. Wayne loved it and had Ben Billions to put the entire song together.

In an interview after the album’s release, Wayne revealed that he had no idea who X was and that X’s inclusion was Mack Maine’s idea.

That was my big homie Mack’s idea. He came to New Orleans to do something for like a day or two, and he came back and said I have something I want you to hear. That was the first time hearing my mom on the song, so when he played that, then he played the song.

Although X never heard this song, he probably would have approved of it because he often cited Wayne as one of his biggest influences. He revealed that Wayne was one of his favorite rappers in his XXL interview, and he also mentioned that he grew up listening to Wayne in his No Jumper interview and in his interview with 103.5 The Beat.

He also has shouted out Wayne on a song. In the intro to “YuNg BrAtZ,” X says:

She wanna, X wanna
You wanna? L-l-lick my dick like a what? Nice!
Lick my dick like Lil Wayne lollipop, huh!

Additionally, X’s part appears to be somewhat inspired by X’s “Pain = BESTFRIEND.”  He uses some of the same lyrics but sings them in a significantly calmer tone.

songs.full_title: Blunt Blowin' by Lil Wayne
songs.title: Blunt Blowin’

description.plain:
“Blunt Blowin” is a song by Lil Wayne and is the second track off his 9th studio album, Tha Carter IV.

Lil Wayne is synonymous with weed at this point, so it makes sense that he builds his second track’s hook around lighting up. It doesn’t contain his most outrageous narcotic exploits (that honor goes to his blatant disregard for his Grammy) but it has his signature slow flow over some eerie violin chords. There’s also a very clever shout-out to Ashton Kutcher!

songs.full_title: Uproar by Lil Wayne (Ft. Swizz Beatz)
songs.title: Uproar

description.plain:
On this song, Lil Wayne warns his enemies to stop playing with him before he causes an “Uproar.”

The instrumental, produced by Swizz Beatz and Avenue, is a recreation of G-Dep’s 2001 single “Special Delivery,” which Wayne previously remixed on the Dedication 4 track “Green Ranger.” Ironically, on that remix, Wayne stated that he didn’t even like this beat.

songs.full_title: Drop the World by Lil Wayne (Ft. Eminem)
songs.title: Drop the World

description.plain: “Drop the World” is the third single by Lil Wayne, which features Eminem. The song was released on iTunes on December 28, 2009. Lil Wayne, Eminem, and Travis Barker of Blink-182 performed the song together along with Drake’s song “Forever” at the 52nd Grammy Awards in 2010. On June 16, 2010, the single was certified platinum by the RIAA.

description.plain:
New Carter IV release produced by Polow da Don, Rob Holladay, and J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League

As of now the blogosphere is up in debate over what this song is intended for because:


It has pretty much the same beat as “I’m Not A Star” by Rick Ross
The song was removed from iTunes a couple hours after its posting, because the name was changed from “If I Die Today” to “John”



The original title was supposed to be “John Lennon” (but the REAL John Lennon’s estate did not allow this)

songs.full_title: How to Love by Lil Wayne
songs.title: How to Love

description.plain:
Tha Carter IV’s third single. In line with his previous efforts, this acoustic track is a genre bend for the rap game. Once again he’s lamenting a lost love, but in stark contrast to its mirror image How to Hate, this track is sweet and nurturing. Apparently it only takes five tracks for Weezy to have a change of heart.

Check out BigGhost’s Carter IV Review nahmean?

Lollipop (Remix) dropped during the height of rap’s auto-tune suck phase, and was seen by many to exemplify that gimmicky style

But while its sound might be derivative, Lollipop (Remix) is saved by its clever and sophisticated lyrics

songs.full_title: Dedicate by Lil Wayne
songs.title: Dedicate

description.plain:
With “Dedicate,” Lil Wayne acknowledges his influence in the rap game. He also seems to make some subliminal comments towards Birdman.

The song samples 2 Chainz’s “Dedication,” which is itself an ode to Wayne.

As a subtle flex, the track samples one of President Barack Obama’s 2009 speeches in which he stated:

Our kids can’t all aspire to be LeBron or Lil Wayne!

description.plain:
Here, we encounter Wayne’s masterful foray into electropop. He is known to experiment with different genres hence his rock album, Rebirth.

This was his breakout single, and is to date his only song to top the Billboard Hot 100. The song has since been certified 5x platinum.

songs.full_title: God Bless Amerika by Lil Wayne
songs.title: God Bless Amerika

description.plain:
One of the stand-out tracks off I Am Not a Human Being II. Wayne speaks on the harsh realities of the proverbial American Dream and the relentless elusiveness of a triumph over it.

He spells America with a ‘K’ because he’s a blood and bloods don’t say the letter ‘c’ (hint: crips).



The song bears thematic similarities to “President Carter” from Tha Carter IV.

songs.full_title: Let It Fly by Lil Wayne (Ft. Travis Scott)
songs.title: Let It Fly

description.plain:
“Let It Fly” is the second collaboration between Lil Wayne and Travis Scott, following DJ Khaled’s “Tourist” in 2016.

According to DRTWRK, one of the song’s producers, this track was made in 2018 and is not the same song Travis tweeted about in 2014.

songs.full_title: Glory by Lil Wayne
songs.title: Glory

description.plain:
The first single from Lil Wayne’s most recent album, released on June 3, 2015 as a Tidal exclusive. Only a couple hours after the song’s release, it was announced that Wayne is now a co-owner of TIDAL. TIDAL employee Vania Schlogel commented on the addition:

We’re honored for Lil Wayne to join TIDAL. His eagerness to release an exclusive TIDAL track and schedule a TIDAL X performance is just another example of how passionately artists care about getting their music to fans.

https://twitter.com/LilTunechi/status/606130682147028993

This song was re-released as part of the FWA on all platforms in July 2020, featuring slightly altered production.

songs.full_title: It's Good by Lil Wayne (Ft. Drake & Jadakiss)
songs.title: It’s Good

description.plain:
“It’s Good” is a hookless cut between Wayne, Drake, and Jadakiss that was released as the fifth single from Wayne’s ninth studio album, Tha Carter IV. The song’s instrumental is backed by a sample of The Alan Parsons Project’s 1976 song, “The Cask of Amontillado.”

The song received a large amount of buzz from fans due to Lil Wayne’s verse which contained some subliminal shots at Jay-Z, in response to his shot at Birdman on his Kanye West-assisted “H·A·M”—released seven months prior—where he made fun of Birdman’s net worth, calling it “baby money.” In an exclusive Vibe interview, Wayne talked about his diss:

I know there won’t be any repercussions behind what I did. I know for a fact music is about perception. You can’t do anything but perceive what you hear. I know that for a fact. So I can’t ever be upset about someone’s reaction. I’m not going to say I don’t know what would happen before I even say [something on record]. I do know what will happen. I’m aware of it. But it is what it is.

songs.full_title: Family Feud by Lil Wayne (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Family Feud

description.plain:
This song was released on Lil Wayne’s YouTube channel on December 29th, 2017 as part of Dedication 6: Reloaded, a re-release of his Christmas Day project. It is a remix of JAY-Z’s song  “Family Feud.”

Drake and Wayne spend their verses discussing various feuds going on right now including Colin Kaepernick, Universal Music Group, Wayne’s former “father,” Birdman, and many more.

The song is reminiscent of “Ignant Shit,” a cut from Drake’s So Far Gone mixtape, where he and Wayne go bar for bar with no hook as well. The monikers “Young Angel” for Drake and “Young Lion” for Wayne are also used on this song. Both songs also borrow their instrumental from previously released songs by Jay-Z.

songs.full_title: I'm Single by Lil Wayne
songs.title: I’m Single

description.plain:
“I’m Single” is a song by Lil Wayne, released as a single from his ninth mixtape, No Ceilings, and is also included on his eighth studio album I Am Not a Human Being.

The song is produced by Noah “40” Shebib, with co-production from Omen. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics on its release, who complimented its relaxed, downbeat tone and also the production from Shebib and Omen.

songs.full_title: Let It All Work Out by Lil Wayne
songs.title: Let It All Work Out

description.plain:
“Let It All Work Out” is the outro of Wayne’s Tha Carter V and samples soul singer Sampha’s 2013 song “Indecision.”

It initially appeared on a leaked 2014 tracklist and was later confirmed in a 2018 Billboard Magazine’s cover story.

Furthermore, the cover story also revealed that Wayne had added new lyrics—following the suicides of designer Kate Spade and celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain—in which he admits that the incident of him shooting himself at 12 was, in fact, a suicide attempt undertaken after his mother told him he would no longer be allowed to rap.

The song title is a reference to Pink Floyd’s classic 1973 album of the same name.

songs.full_title: I Feel Like Dying by Lil Wayne
songs.title: I Feel Like Dying

description.plain:
A change from Wayne’s usual glorification of drugs, this is seen by many as Wayne’s most introspective song. It’s a meditation on the slippery slope of addiction; everything’s fun and games until the depression and pain of withdrawal hits.

Sample is on the hook Henry Ate’s/Karma’s song “Once,” she later sued him for copyright infringement—Probably the reason why this didn’t make Tha Carter III.

songs.full_title: You Song by Lil Wayne (Ft. Chance the Rapper)
songs.title: You Song

description.plain:
When asked if it was about a specific girl:

I was thinking about a specific girl, but I wanted it to be universal at the same time. That’s the big thing with making music, you want something that everyone can apply to their own lives, but there’s still a certain specificity. I wanted to be speaking about a black woman.

In this interview with Sway, Chance speaks about how Wayne actually delayed the release of D5 specifically to get Chance on this song.

songs.full_title: Nightmares of the Bottom by Lil Wayne
songs.title: Nightmares of the Bottom

description.plain:
Previewed early in a Lil Wayne “I Am The Music Tour” freestyle, this song plays on the age old “lonely at the top” cliche, but revealing the inverse- the fear of a fall from grace. It’s uncharacteristically heartfelt and sentimental, including a rare admission of his fallibility, but as with most of Wayne’s songs it falls back into exaggerated bravado. Of particular note is the resurrection of his Weezy F Baby nickname, one of the rapper’s many, many aliases.



Check out BigGhost’s Carter IV Review nahmean?

description.plain: This song is what the title implies: an “Open Letter” from Wayne to his fans, family, friends, and life in general. With a single verse lasting a continuous four and a half minutes, Wayne discusses numerous topics that have been on his mind, notably revealing that he has contemplated suicide and had feelings of self-hatred.

body.plain: This song is what the title implies: an “Open Letter” from Wayne to his fans, family, friends, and life in general. With a single verse lasting a continuous four and a half minutes, Wayne discusses numerous topics that have been on his mind, notably revealing that he has contemplated suicide and had feelings of self-hatred.

songs.lyrics:
[Intro]
Ah-em

[Verse 1]
Sometimes I feel like I ain't shit
Sometimes a nigga feel like shit
Talkin’ 'bout some real life shit
Goodbye letter, "Dear Life" shit
So if a nigga kill me, hope he mean it
I just hope I die for a reason
They probably won't miss me ’til they need me
Have problems with admittin' that they need me, Lord
I'm talkin' 'bout some real life shit
Goodbye letter, "Dear Life" shit
Way too concerned to be conceited
I live and I learn, then die tryna teach 'em, Lord
Die tryna reach 'em
They care more about how much I leave than
Where I leave it
I hope I leave more of an impression on my kids
To be destined to have blessings to believe in, Lord
Just got off the phone with my son
Told him, "You're a son of a gun"
Just got off the phone with my daughter
Told her, "I won’t hesitate to fuck a young nigga up", Lord
A few bitches left me, that only got a new bitch elected
My old bitch was too disrespectful

Can’t lie though, I tried though
I'll die tryin', that's a common death

Then it stopped, now I'm outta breath
Now they try to tell me I need rest
And I'll find love again, I ain't find it yet
Oh, but I guess it is what it is as it appears, oh shit
The object in the mirror is more near than it appears, oh shit
And sometimes I fear who in the mirror, that nigga weird
He done died so many times but still here, why am I here?

[Chorus]
Dear Life
What is my meaning? My reason?

[Verse 2]
Naked bitches really love ones
Sometimes our loved ones don't love us
I'm fuckin' more than I'm makin' love
Sometimes I make my rubber wear a rubber
I just tell my lady, "Nothing's easy"
Even though I make it look easy
But understand looks are deceiving
Lookin' like I'm lookin' for some grievance
'Cause I been through way too much, don't wanna think about it
Cranky 'bout it, gotta drink about it
Gotta synchronize it, tranquilize it
Doctor ain't prescribin' what he ain't realizin'
Pain inside me got me thinkin' 'bout me
Tryna hang my body, sanctifyin'

I can't deny it, you can't tame my lion
I'm a angry lion hangin' by a string, I can't describe it
Feel like a anchor tied to my finger
Got me sinkin' to the bottom of my drink
I know a lotta niggas think I got a lotta niggas
There's strength in numbers but it's honor over strength
I talked to God the other day, he say he got a nigga
So, I look death up in her eye and then I wink
It's way too real, the shit I'm talkin' way, way too real
I hope it gave you chills
The dirt under your feet could be the grave you fill
You don't know how dead you feel 'til you're dead for real
Gettin' high after I paid the bill, lower than a Navy SEAL
Show up with them Navy guns, I hope somebody prayin' for 'em
Price tags no mistakes, somebody payin' for 'em
Ice bath when my face numb, no expression
What's the life expectancy when you don't expect shit?
Mama told me, "Fuck the world and be so aggressive
Be self-fluorescent, watch these hoes 'cause they so obsessive
Don't get too high to look over blessings
Never come in second, make the most of your seconds
They so precious"
'Cause if we could buy time, every store would sell it
If you want me to read your mind, need correct spelling
I keep it real, niggas better keep it copacetic
Where the weed? I feel like I'm gettin' a sober headache
Lookin' in the mirror at the one that know me better
I was too busy to talk, I wrote an open letter

[Chorus]
Dear Life
What is my meaning? My reason?
That's the question I ask the reader, God bless the reader
Dear Life, what is my meaning? My reason?
That's the question

[Outro: Jacida Carter]
You know, when he told me Toya was havin' a baby, I say, "Y'all young. You know y'all young." But I said, "Be the best father you can be," you know. And truly, he is that.

songs.title_with_featured: Mrs. Officer (Ft. Bobby V & Kidd Kidd)

description.plain:
A radio song with Bobby Valentino singing a lovey-dovey hook…certainly nothing intellectual going on here, right? Except that you dealing with Lil Wayne! The female officer featured in the song is purely fictitious (he even proposes to her at the end… not a very Lil Waynish thing to do)..

The purpose of the song is to emasculate all of the male police officers who fuck with Lil Wayne on the daily

description.plain:
This is the opening song of Lil Wayne’s 3x platinum album, Tha Carter 3

In the title, Wayne is playing on the notion of “3-peating” in sports (winning 3 championships in a row) to say that this is his third straight “championship” album
